factoid: The seventh party consisted of people who are always found around young sovereigns.
The seventh party included many generals around Emperor Alexander.
The seventh party included many imperial aides‑de‑camp around Emperor Alexander.
These generals and aides‑de‑camp were passionately devoted to the Emperor.
These generals and aides‑de‑camp adored the Emperor as a man, not just as a monarch.
These generals and aides‑de‑camp adored the Emperor sincerely and disinterestedly.
These generals and aides‑de‑camp admired the Emperor as Rostóv had done in 1805.
These generals and aides‑de‑camp saw the Emperor as possessing all virtues.
These generals and aides‑de‑camp saw the Emperor as possessing all human capabilities.
These men were enchanted with the Emperor for refusing the command of the army.
These men blamed the Emperor for excessive modesty.
These men desired that the Emperor abandon his diffidence.
These men wanted the Emperor to openly announce that he would place himself at the head of the army.
These men wanted the Emperor to gather around him a commander‑in‑chief's staff.
These men wanted the Emperor to consult experienced theoreticians and practical men where necessary.
These men wanted the Emperor to lead the troops himself.
These men believed that if the Emperor led the troops, the troops' spirits would be raised to the highest pitch.
The eighth group was the largest group.
The eighth group was ninety‑nine to one in size compared to the other groups.
The eighth group consisted of men who desired neither peace nor war.
The eighth group desired neither an advance nor a defensive camp at the Drissa or anywhere else.
The eighth group desired neither Barclay nor the Emperor.
The eighth group desired neither Pfuel nor Benningsen.
The eighth group desired only advantage and pleasure for themselves as possible.
In the troubled waters of conflicting and intersecting intrigues around the Emperor’s headquarters, many ways of succeeding were possible that were unthinkable at other times.
A man who wished to retain his lucrative post might agree with Pfuel today.
The same man might agree with his opponent tomorrow.
The same man might declare that he had no opinion to avoid responsibility or to please the Emperor.
Another man who wished to gain some advantage would attract the Emperor’s attention by loudly advocating what the Emperor had hinted at the day before.
That man would dispute and shout at the council.
That man would beat his breast and challenge those who did not agree with him to duels.
That man proved he was prepared to sacrifice himself for the common good.
A third man, lacking opponents, would solicit a special gratuity for his faithful services between two councils.
That man knew people would be too busy to refuse him at that moment.
A fourth man, seemingly overwhelmed with work, would often come accidentally under the Emperor’s eye.
A fifth man, to achieve his aim of dining with the Emperor, would stubbornly insist on the correctness or falsity of some newly emerging opinion.
That man would produce arguments more or less forcible and correct to support his stance.
All men of the eighth party were fishing for rubles, decorations, and promotions.
These men watched only the weathercock of imperial favor.
These men directly noticed the weathercock turning in any direction.
The whole drone population of the army began blowing hard in that direction.
It was harder for the Emperor to turn the army elsewhere.

Amid uncertainties and menace of serious danger, the vortex of intrigue, egotism, conflict of views and feelings, and diversity of race among these people caused great confusion and obscurity to the common task.
Whenever a question arose, a swarm of these drones flew over to the new question.
The drones’ hum drowned and obscured the voices of those disputing honestly.
At the time Prince Andrew reached the army, a ninth party was being formed.
The ninth party was beginning to raise its voice.
The ninth party was the party of the elders.
The elders were reasonable men experienced and capable in state affairs.
The elders did not share conflicting opinions.
The elders could take a detached view of what was going on at the staff at headquarters.
The elders considered means of escape from the muddle, indecision, intricacy, and weakness.
The men of the ninth party believed that what was wrong resulted chiefly from the Emperor’s presence in the army with his military court.
The men of the ninth party believed that the presence of an indefinite, conditional, and unsteady fluctuation of relations was harmful in an army.
The men of the ninth party believed a sovereign should reign but not command the army.
The men of the ninth party believed the only way out of the position was for the Emperor and his court to leave the army.
The men of the ninth party believed the mere presence of the Emperor paralyzed the action of fifty thousand men required to secure his personal safety.
The men of the ninth party believed the worst commander in chief, if independent, would be better than the very best one trammeled by the presence and authority of the monarch.
